Drepanosiphum platanoidis, commonly known as the Norway maple aphid, is a species of aphid that primarily feeds on the leaves of Norway maple trees (Acer platanoides). This aphid species belongs to the order Hemiptera and the family Drepanosiphidae.

The Norway maple aphid is a small, pear-shaped insect with a soft, green or yellowish-green body. They have a pair of long, slender antennae and a pair of cornicles (exhaust pipes) at the rear of their abdomen. These aphids reproduce asexually, and their colonies can grow rapidly, often causing significant damage to the host plant.

Drepanosiphum platanoidis feeds on the sap of Norway maple leaves, which can lead to the development of yellowing, curling, or distorted leaves. In severe infestations, the aphids can cause premature leaf drop, reduced tree vigor, and increased susceptibility to other pests and diseases.

This aphid species is found throughout Europe and parts of Asia, where its host plant, the Norway maple, is commonly cultivated as an ornamental tree. Understanding the biology and ecology of Drepanosiphum platanoidis is important for developing effective management strategies to control its populations and minimize the impact on Norway maple trees.
